myth: 🧠Calories in, calories out is all that matters
truth: Calorie balance is important, but factors like hormones, metabolism, and sleep also play major roles in weight and health.
Healthy fats from avocados, nuts, and fish are essential for brain function and hormone production.
Whole carbs like brown rice and beans are nutritious; it's refined carbs that are problematic.
Moderate egg consumption is safe for most people and provides high-quality protein and nutrients.
Your liver and kidneys naturally detox your body, most detox products are unnecessary.
Skipping meals can slow metabolism and lead to overeating later.

myth: 🧂Sea salt is healthier than table salt
truth: Both have similar sodium content; moderation is key regardless of type.

myth: 🥛Dairy is the only source of calcium
truth: Leafy greens, tofu, sardines, and fortified plant milks also provide calcium.

myth: 🥩You need meat to get enough protein
truth: Plant-based proteins like beans and lentils can meet your needs when combined well.
Only in moderation and when low in sugar and high in cocoa content.

myth: 🥬Fresh produce is always better than frozen
truth: Frozen fruits and veggies can be just as nutritious, sometimes even more so.

myth: 🥣Breakfast is the most important meal of the day
truth: Not for everyone, some thrive with intermittent fasting or delayed eating.

myth: 🧁Natural sugars like honey are healthier than white sugar
truth: Your body processes them similarly; both should be used sparingly.
Some contain artificial sweeteners that may affect gut health or appetite.

myth: 🧃Juicing is better than eating whole fruits
truth: Juicing removes fiber and can spike blood sugar; whole fruits are more balanced.
